docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his opposition to a requirement that Federal health plans cover contraceptives, Representative Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, shows a lack of understanding (front page, Oct. 14). You report that Mr. Coburn does not want Depo-Provera and intrauterine devices covered because he maintains that they interfere with fertilization and therefore cause abortions.

headline.main: Congress's Budget-Making: Not a Pretty Sight

docs.abstract: Harriet Horowitz letter, commenting on October 14 article on high-stakes budget battle on Capitol Hill, says Republican Repr Tom Coburn shows lack of understanding in his opposition to budget proposal that Federal health plans cover contraceptives
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In his opposition to a requirement that Federal health plans cover contraceptives, Representative Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, shows a lack of understanding (front page, Oct. 14). You report that Mr. Coburn does not want...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the closing days of the 20th century, new financial rules are being written that will undermine the principles of capitalism and lay the foundation for a new economic order of not-so-free free markets. Today's system, based on open competition with minimal intervention, has come under attack from an unlikely coalition of Wall Street financiers, economists and Washington power brokers. In their attempts to rescue failing markets and control crashing currencies, these interventionists in free-market clothing are promoting policies to restrict the natural movement of money. After years of global overspeculation, the market is undergoing a violent upheaval in an effort to bring itself back to health.
docs.snippet: In the closing days of the 20th century, new financial rules are being written that will undermine the principles of capitalism and lay the foundation for a new economic order of not-so-free free markets.    Today's system, based on open competition...

docs.lead_paragraph: Their hopes for a big tax cut this year having been blocked by President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, Republican leaders tentatively agreed tonight on a sharply scaled-back package that kept alive several politically popular tax breaks. After several days in which squabbling among Republicans endangered efforts to pass any tax bill this year, House and Senate negotiators compromised as Congress raced to finish work on the budget and go home to campaign.

headline.main: G.O.P. Agrees on Scaled-Back Tax Package

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators, after days in which squabbling among Republicans endangered efforts to pass any tax bill, tentatively agree on sharply scaled-back package that extends for few more months some politically popular tax breaks; package includes tax breaks for corporate research and development, employers who hire welfare recipients and other unemployed people and farmers hit hard by falling prices; would speed existing plan to let self-employed deduct all of their health insurance premiums; package would cost about $5 billion over five years and $9.2 billion over 10 years; would be paid for by closing loopholes and extending or raising other taxes; Senate Finance Committee head Sen William V Roth Jr objects to some details, especially provision demanded by Sen Phil Gramm involving Texas university students (M)
docs.snippet: Their hopes for a big tax cut this year having been blocked by President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, Republican leaders tentatively agreed tonight on a sharply scaled-back package that kept alive several politically popular tax breaks.   ...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Every pregnant woman in the country should be checked for the AIDS virus as part of routine prenatal care, an expert panel said today in recommending a policy change that could further reduce cases of babies' being infected at birth. Pregnant women infected with the virus can greatly reduce the chances of passing it to their infants if they take anti-viral drugs, but many are not being tested. Under Federal guidelines, doctors are encouraged to counsel women about the virus and suggest an AIDS screening test. The new recommendations call for reducing the amount of pre-test counseling in many cases and informing women that they will be tested for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, unless they object.

headline.main: Panel Urges H.I.V. Tests For All Pregnant Women

docs.abstract: Institute of Medicine panel recommends every pregnant woman in United States be tested for AIDS virus as part of routine prenatal care; Dr Marie McCormick, panel chairwoman, says move would help prevent HIV infection in newborns and could be achieved without great deal of added cost, interview (M)
